'''Halvar C. Jonson''' (born August 14, 1941 [[Athabasca, Alberta|Athabasca]], [[Alberta]] [[Canada]]). is a former teacher and high school principal. He was also a long serving provincial politician from [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. He served as a member of the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]] and cabinet minister in the provincial government from 1982 until 2004. ==Early life== Jonson was born in [[Athabasca, Alberta|Athabasca]], [[Alberta]] [[Canada]] on August 14, 1941.<ref name="rec">{{cite web|url=http://www.gunzburger.com/Jonson-Halvar.htm|title=Halvar C. Jonson | author=Ron Gunzburger|publisher=Politics1 Canada}}</ref> He served as president of the [[Alberta Teachers' Association]] from 1976 until 1977.<ref name="teachprez">{{cite web|url=http://www.teachers.ab.ca/About+the+ATA/History/Past+Presidents.htm | title=Past Presidents | publisher=Alberta Teachers' Association|accessdate=2008-03-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071015094130/http://www.teachers.ab.ca/About+the+ATA/History/Past+Presidents.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-10-15}}</ref> ==Political career== Jonson was first elected to the Alberta Legislature in the [[Alberta general election, 1982|1982 Alberta general election]]. He defeated Tom Butterfield from the [[Western Canada Concept]] and three other candidates to win his first term in office. His win held the [[Ponoka (provincial electoral district)|Ponoka]] electoral district for the [[Progressive Conservative Association of Alberta|Progressive Conservatives]].<ref name="elec1">{{cite web|url=http://www.abheritage.ca/abpolitics/database/maps_choice.asp?Year=1982&Constit=Ponoka | title=Ponoka election results 1982 general election|publisher=Alberta Heritage|accessdate=2008-03-22}}</ref> Due to redistribution of electoral district boundaries in the [[Alberta general election, 1986|1986 Alberta general election]] Ponoka was abolished and re-created as [[Ponoka-Rimbey]]. Jonson ran for his second term in the new electoral district and won easily defeating three other candidates. He stood for a third term in office in the [[Alberta general election, 1989|1989 Alberta general election]] fending off a strong challenge from Doug Hart of the [[Alberta New Democratic Party|New Democrats]] and one other candidate.<ref name="elec2">{{cite web|url=http://www.abheritage.ca/abpolitics/database/maps_choice.asp?Year=198&Constit=Ponoka-Rimbey | title=Ponoka-Rimbey election results 1986-1989 general election|publisher=Alberta Heritage|accessdate=2008-03-22}}</ref>
Jonson would see his popular vote grow in his bid for a fourth term for office in the [[Alberta general election, 1993|1993 Alberta general election]]. He was easily reelected defeating four other candidates. He would be returned for a fifth consecutive term. The race for the [[Alberta general election, 1997|1997 Alberta general election]] would see support build for second place Randy Jones of [[Social Credit Party of Alberta|Social Credit]].<ref name="elec3">{{cite web|url=http://www.abheritage.ca/abpolitics/database/maps_choice.asp?Year=199&Constit=Ponoka-Rimbey | title=Ponoka-Rimbey election results 1993-1997 general election|publisher=Alberta Heritage|accessdate=2008-03-22}}</ref> Jonson would see his popular support marginally drop but still win the electoral district by a wide margin. In the [[Alberta general election, 2001|2001 Alberta general election]], Jonson would set a personal record for the largest plurality of his career. He would be returned to the Legislature in a landslide for his sixth and final term.<ref name="elec4">{{cite web|url=http://www.abheritage.ca/abpolitics/database/maps_choice.asp?Year=2001&Constit=Ponoka-Rimbey | title=Ponoka-Rimbey election results 2001 general election|publisher=Alberta Heritage|accessdate=2008-03-22}}</ref> Jonson retired at dissolution of the Legislature in 2004. His electoral district of Ponoka-Rimbey was abolished due to redistribution. ==Late life and legacy== In honour of Jonson's public service the provincial government renamed the brain injury ward of the Alberta Hospital Ponoka, the Halvar Jonson Centre for Brain Injury in [[Ponoka, Alberta|Ponoka]], [[Alberta]] <ref name="brain">{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/David-Thompson-Health-Region-Alberta-Hospital-Ponoka-is-Renamed-The-Centennial-Centre-615190.htm |title=David Thompson Health Region renames Alberta Hospital Ponoka the Centennial Centre for Mental Health and Brain Injury |work=article |year=2006 |accessdate=06 April 2011 |quote=...  In addition, the brain injury unit has been renamed the Halvar Jonson Centre for Brain Injury in recognition of the longtime area MLA who contributed significantly to healthcare in this province, to the development of this specialized campus and to the community of Ponoka. ...' }}</ref>
